Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Use and Abuse of Zircon Thermometry - Integrating Modeling, Trace Element Chemistry and Isotopes to Maximize the Use, Limit the Abuse
Award.AbstractNarration:
Zircon (ZrSiO4) is arguably the single most powerful mineral for elucidating the evolution of the continental crust. The proposal will take advantage of the ability of zircon to record the temperature history of magma generated in the crust. We will specifically target granites produced in the period of earth history at approximately 1.05 billion years ago (the Grenville orogenic event). Our prior research demonstrated that this is a unique episode for generation of large volumes of exceptionally hot (900-1100 oC) granitic magma. The fingerprint of these hot granites includes high zirconium contents and conspicuously high modal abundance of zircon that does not contain xenocrysts of prior zircon (i.e., the zircon is not recycled from other crustal rocks and represents a primary chemical/mineralogic feature of the granites). Preliminary chemical analysis of the zircon in the hot granites demonstrates that the zircon also has high titanium contents, which prove high zircon crystallization temperatures. Computer modeling of the crystallization history of the high zirconium granites also demonstrates that zircon begins crystallization at ~1000 oC. The important insight from these preliminary results regarding the evolution of the Earth?s crust is that there must be unique lithospheric conditions in order to generate such hot granites.

The proposed research will target for study a much larger suite of granites from the Grenville Blue Ridge Province in eastern North America (Shenandoah massif, Virginia) where we have identified a terrane-wide occurrence of high zirconium granites. The purpose of the research is to more thoroughly elucidate the temperature history of the Grenville granite suite and examine in detail the chemical and textural relationship of zircon to the bulk rock chemistry and modal mineralogy, in order to more precisely ascertain the conditions at which the zircon crystallized. We will conduct whole rock geochemical analysis, crystallization modeling using the program rhyoliteMELTS, cathodolomuninescence imaging of individual zircon grains to explore for potential xenocrysts, and ion microprobe analysis of trace elements and isotopes in zircon. The research will be conducted by graduate and undergraduate students from the collaborating institutions, providing critical training for future geoscientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magma generation is one of the fundamental processes that result from plate tectonic processes on planet Earth. Volcanic eruptions are the most spectacular manifestation of magma generation, which can have consequences for people living near the volcano (ash flows, CO2 emission) or the entire world (climate change impacts) if magma is erupted in larger volumes (supervolcanoes). Crystallization of magma may result in economic concentrations of ore minerals that can be mined. Understanding the how-why-what and when of magma formation and crystallization is therefore an important endeavor to pursue to better understand our planet.

The tools used by petrologists to understand magma generation are largely chemical in nature, i.e., we use the chemical composition of the magma and of minerals that crystallize from the magma to calculate parameters such as the temperature at which the magma was generated in the magma source region in the crust. This study examined zircon (ZrSiO4), a common accessory mineral in granitic magma and probably the most widely utuilized mineral in geology for understanding magma genesis. Because of its wide use and the reliance of petrologists on zircon in granite geothermometry ("taking the temperature of magma") it was worth comparing the accuracy and geologic meaning of the zircon thermometers. This comparison was conducted on samples of Grenville-aged (ca. 1 billion year old) granite that have high Zr contents and generated large amounts of zircon crystals formed during the entire crystallization history of the magma. Using instruments that can determine the age and chemical composition of sand-grain-sized zircon crystals; scanning electron microscopes for imaging the textural features of the microscopic zircon grains; and instruments for measuring the chemical composition of rocks, we compared three different zircon geothermometers:

1. Zircon saturation thermometer, which reflects the temperature at which zircon begins crystallizing in the magma

2. Ti-in-zircon thermometer

3. Computer modeling to replicate the crystallization process and predict the onset of zircon crystallization.

The primary research findings are the following:

1. For high Zr granites, all the zircon thermometers converge and are in agreement and correspond to the high temperature onset of zircon crystallization. This agreement is unusual because for most granites zircon thermometers are not in agreement, for various geological reasons, but primarily because the granites have low Zr concentrations (<300 ppm). The magma does not reach zircon saturation until low temperature (600-800oC) and zircon crystallizes late, yielding Ti-in-zircon temperatures that are lower than zircon saturation temperatures.

2. Ti concentration of zircon for each sample ranges from 5 to 50 ppm, and Ti-in-zircon temperatures range from 800 to 1050oC. These ranges reflect the fact that zircon crystallizes over a range of termperature in the same manner that the modal phase assemblage (quartz, feldspars, pyroxene) crystallizes.

3. Temperatures for the high-Zr Grenville-aged granites approach 1050oC, which are some of the highest granite temperatures ever reported.

4. The high temperartures for the Grenville suite of granites supports the assertion that the conditions for granite generation were unlike those at any other time in earth history. As a future line of research, computational models for lithospheric geodynamics of various crustal-mantle scenarios will be conducted to reproduce the high temperature conditions.

The research was conducted by two female college students at the University of Kentucky, in collaboration with faculty from Syracuse University, and at several laboratories around the country. These students gained experience using analytical instrumentation, in the methods of.data collection and interpretation, report writing and publication, and in presentation of the results to the public at professional meetings. Both students now hold positions as professional geoscientists. The experience gained by participating in this project was an invaluable component of their professional development.
